guideline.name: Annotation of DPWG Guideline for phenytoin and CYP2C9

relatedGenes.name: cytochrome P450 family 2 subfamily C member 9

gene.name: cytochrome P450 family 2 subfamily C member 9

recommendation.html: The guideline does not provide a recommendation for phenytoin in normal metabolizers.

implications.html: The guideline does not provide a description of the impact of a normal metabolizer phenotype on phenytoin.

recommendation.html:
1. The loading dose does not need to be adjusted.
  2. For the other doses, use 75% of the standard dose and assess the dose based on effect and serum concentration after 7-10 days.
  3. Advise the patient to get in touch if side effects (such as ataxia, nystagmus, slurred speech, sedation or rash) occur.

implications.html: Genetic variation reduces conversion of phenytoin to inactive metabolites. This increases the risk of side effects.

recommendation.html:
1. The loading dose does not need to be adjusted.
  2. For the other doses, use 75% of the standard dose and assess the dose based on effect and serum concentration after 7-10 days.
  3. Advise the patient to get in touch if side effects (such as ataxia, nystagmus, slurred speech, sedation or rash) occur.

implications.html: Genetic variation reduces conversion of phenytoin to inactive metabolites. This increases the risk of side effects.

recommendation.html:
1. The loading dose does not need to be adjusted.
  2. For the other doses, use 75% of the standard dose and assess the dose based on effect and serum concentration after 7-10 days.
  3. Advise the patient to get in touch if side effects (such as ataxia, nystagmus, slurred speech, sedation or, especially in Asian patients, rash) occur.

implications.html: Genetic variation reduces conversion of phenytoin to inactive metabolites. This increases the risk of side effects. The life-threatening cutaneous side effects Stevens-Johnson Syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis may occur, especially in Asian patients.

recommendation.html:
1. The loading dose does not need to be adjusted.
  2. For the other doses, use 40-50% of the standard dose and assess the dose based on effect and serum concentration after 7-10 days.
  3. Advise the patient to get in touch if side effects (such as ataxia, nystagmus, slurred speech, sedation or rash) occur.

implications.html: Genetic variation reduces conversion of phenytoin to inactive metabolites. This increases the risk of side effects.

recommendation.html:
1. The loading dose does not need to be adjusted.
  2. For the other doses, use 50% of the standard dose and assess the dose based on effect and serum concentration after 7-10 days.
  3. Advise the patient to get in touch if side effects (such as ataxia, nystagmus, slurred speech, sedation or rash) occur.

implications.html: Genetic variation reduces conversion of phenytoin to inactive metabolites. This increases the risk of side effects.

1. The loading dose does not need to be adjusted.
  2. For the other doses, use 50% of the standard dose and assess the dose based on effect and serum concentration after 7-10 days.
  3. Advise the patient to get in touch if side effects (such as ataxia, nystagmus, slurred speech, sedation or rash) occur.

implications.html: Genetic variation reduces conversion of phenytoin to inactive metabolites. This increases the risk of side effects.

recommendation.html:
1. The loading dose does not need to be adjusted.
  2. For the other doses, use 40% of the standard dose and assess the dose based on effect and serum concentration after 7-10 days.
  3. Advise the patient to get in touch if side effects (such as ataxia, nystagmus, slurred speech, sedation or, especially in Asian patients, rash) occur.

implications.html: Genetic variation reduces conversion of phenytoin to inactive metabolites. This increases the risk of side effects. The life-threatening cutaneous side effects Stevens-Johnson Syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis may occur, especially in Asian patients.
